sentence: Stocks aren't expected to behave much differently than they did yesterday, though sentiment on global growth should be a bit better today following positive data out of Germany.
On the home front, the wholesale inflation read was a bit on the hot side, but inflation isn't on anyone's list of worries at this stage.

The November survey from Germany's ZEW Institute came in better than expected this morning, rebounding from the sharp drop the month before when the sentiment measure had fallen into negative territory for the first time in two years.
The November measure came in at +11.5 vs. estimates of +0.9 and last month's reading of -3.6.
Please note that the ZEW survey isn't a measure of consumer confidence; it samples financial professionals like analysts and economists, and as such is considered a proxy for business confidence.
The ZEW institute noted in the release that while conditions have stabilized, they nevertheless remain fragile.
The ZEW survey shows that while growth will likely be no materially better in the December quarter, sentiment has started looking up for the period beyond that.
This is a net positive for the European outlook overall as Germany accounts for almost a third of Euro-zone output.
Hard to tell, however, how this will play out in the market's ongoing expectation for greater monetary stimulus from the European Central Bank (ECB).
We know that Germany has been a holdout in letting the ECB go all the way in meeting investor expectations.
But an improving business outlook in that country would normally be expected to harden their stance even more.
But that's not how the markets are seeing the ZEW survey as the positive stock market reaction today in Germany and elsewhere in Europe shows.
The positive German news today comes after Japan's unexpected descent into another recession on Monday - the country's fourth since 2008.

Stocks were up in Japan today as well after prime minister Abe announced delaying the onset of the second round of sales tax increases; he also announced snap elections to get a fresh mandate for continuing with his Abenomics policies.
Japanese investors are hoping that the incoming government will need to follow fiscally expansive policies to jumpstart growth and to complement the Bank of Japan's easy-money policies.
These policies haven't produced the desired results in Japan despite having been in place for years now, but markets nevertheless like more stimulus.
German attitude towards sovereign QE from the ECB is unlikely to change favorably given the Japanese experience.
But markets seem convinced that the ECB is moving in that direction.
In corporate news, we got a better-than-expected earnings report from Home Depot ( HD ).
The company had recently suffered a data breach, though the full extent of the costs associated with that breach are still unclear.
The stock has been a stellar performer this year - up more than +19% in the year-to-date period - ahead of its rival Lowe's ( LOW ) as well as the broader retail space.
Lowe's reports results Wednesday morning.

Sheraz Mian
